Award.AwardTitle: Design and Characterization of Compact Discharge Units for Advanced LIGO
Award.AbstractNarration:
One of the remaining risks for the success of the Advanced Laser Interferometer Gravitational-Wave Observatory (LIGO) is excess noise due to charge accumulation on the mirrors used as test masses in the interferometer. Research funded by this award will lead to the construction of compact discharge units (CDUs) that can be used to mitigate the charge on the test masses. Each unit features a steerable, low-energy electron beam to neutralize positive charges and a wide angle UV beam to photo-eject negative charges. The CDUs will be optimized for size, reliability, and discharge current within the UV-radiation level tolerable for the optical coating of the Advanced LIGO test masses. Testing of the units will be performed with an existing torsion balance that can measure the absolute charge on an insulator with conducting surface.

In fact, charge mitigation is important for a variety of precision mechanical experiments, including Advanced LIGO, torsion balances, and inertial masses in satellites. In all these systems, a sensitive test mass is electrically isolated from its surroundings. Charge accumulation can lead to spurious coupling between a test mass and nearby surfaces. This unwanted coupling leads to excess noise, degrading the performance of the experiments. The compact discharge unit can be used to reduce this extraneous noise by neutralizing charge on the test mass. Graduate students will participate in this project.

POR.DRECONTENT:
We have developed an absolute-rotation sensor which could be used to measure and reject ground rotation noise and potentially improve the sensitivity of gravitational-wave detectors such as Advanced LIGO (Laser Interferometer Gravitational-wave Observatory). The rotation sensor is more sensitive than other sensors of this type by more than an order of magnitude. It also has potential applications in the field of rotational seismology.

Advanced LIGO aims to measure gravitational waves which are tiny ripples of space-time induced by violent astrophysical phenomena such as collision of neutron stars or supernova explosions. To do this, it measures the separation between mirrors suspended four kilometers apart to a precision of nearly a millionth of an atomic nucleus. Ordinary ground motion, which is larger by more than ten orders of magnitude, is an important source of noise. An absolute-rotation sensor allows a precise measurement of ground motion which can then be used to reduce the effect of ground motion on the mirrors allowing a clean measurement of the gravitational-wave signal.

The rotation sensor measurement provides useful information about ground motion and hence will also be useful in the field of seismology. The attached figure illustrates the sensitivity of the rotation sensor. The figure shows the groun rotation measured by the sensor in response to a person stepping back and forth every twenty seconds at a distance of 12 feet from it.
